title: AB 2676
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 17052.6 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow a credit against the "net tax" for expenses related to household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The credit amount is based on the Internal Revenue Code and is a percentage of the allowable federal credit without considering federal tax liability. For taxable years before January 1, 2003, a credit against the "net tax" is allowed for expenses related to household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of credit for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. Income brackets dictate the credit percentage, ranging from 63% for $40,000 or less to 0% for over $100,000. Different percentages apply for taxable years before 2003, between 2003 and 2016, and after 2016. Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of credit for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The credit percentage ranges from 65% for $40,000 or less to 0% for over $100,000. Different percentages apply for various income brackets. Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of credit for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The credit percentage ranges from 50% for $40,000 or less to 0% for over $100,000. Different percentages apply for various income brackets. The credit authorized by this section is limited to employment-related expenses for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment in the state. Earned income subject to tax under this part is also limited for active members of the Armed Forces. For active members of the Armed Forces, earned income, excluding pensions or retired pay, is subject to tax in the state. The definition of a qualifying individual for tax purposes is modified to include children as defined by the Internal Revenue Code. For tax purposes, a custodial parent is defined as the one providing over half of the child's support during the year. This designation allows the child to be considered a qualifying individual under the Internal Revenue Code. The child must receive over half of their support from parents who never married and lived apart during the last six months of the year. The child must also be in the custody of one or both parents for more than half of the year. Amendments to this section apply to taxable years starting in 2002 and 2011. This act enacts a tax levy under the Constitution and takes immediate effect.
